roleset.name: put a load on someone/thing, the act of putting a load on someone (the act!!!)

example.name: all args
example.text: Avery paid $750 million, including various legal and financing fees, to acquire Uniroyal Chemical, Middlebury, Conn., in 1986 -- a move that burdened Avery with debt.

example.name: passive with with
example.text: But some other analysts have a stormier forecast for the pound, particularly because Britain's inflation is hovering at a relatively lofty annual rate of about 7.6% and the nation is burdened with a struggling government and large current account and trade deficits.
example.arg: with a struggling government and large current account and trade deficits.

example.name: careful: passive with by
example.text: If Sen. Bradley would permit a vote on capital gains, though, it would pass, Christmas retail sales would be strong instead of burdened by a falling stock market, the 1990 economy would be robust, and the revenue gains at every level of government, including New Jersey's, would be surprisingly high.

roleset.note: BURDEN-V NOTES: Frames file for 'burden' based on sentences in financial subcorpus andautomatic expansion via verbnet. (from burden.01-v predicate notes)
BURDEN-N NOTES: Added by Julia based on BOLT, burden-v.01. Corresponds to VNcls equip-13.4.2-1-1 (from burden.01-n)

This nominalization differs somewhat from the verb frame. There is not expected to be an agentive burdener here, only a thing that is a burden, and specific aspect of that thing that is particularly a burden, hence the slightly different args. Compare to 'hassle-n.01' instead. Please watch out for instances that describe the load istelf, rather than the experience of heaviness. It can be blurry, but do your best. (from burden.01-n)
